p: In the study conducted by Kozicky et al. [ 109], authors found that macrophages treated with IVIg showed an increased production of IL-10, with a reduction in IL-12/23p40, thus suggesting the promotion of an anti-inflammatory macrophage profile. Although there is no evidence of macrophage pulmonary migration inhibition by IVIg, a study on induced peripheral neurotoxicity showed that this treatment reduced nerve macrophage infiltration in rats [ 110]. These observations deserve attention in those patients treated with CP-COVID-19 since they may account for the positive results encountered in critically ill patients with COVID-19 [ 38, 39]. In this line, we argue for CP-COVID-19 administration in early stages of diseases to prevent innate immune cells migration and avoid lung damage.
